Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Preserving weather information from Inuit Elders and remote weather stations at Clyde River, Nunavut

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project continued previous research and addressed the need to preserve two key sources of weather information on Baffin Island: (i) Inuit Elders’ and hunters’ observations and traditional knowledge of weather; and (ii) weather data from three remote automated weather stations.

We found that Inuit Elders and hunters are keenly interested in revitalizing, preserving, and passing on traditional knowledge related to weather, weather observation and forecasting to younger generations. Though traditional weather knowledge has eroded since the time when Inuit lived a traditional way of life on the land, there are still Elders who hold this knowledge, are interested in this knowledge, and are willing to share their experience and skills. Younger generations of hunters and youth are very interested in learning this knowledge. While both younger and older generations of hunters use modern tools for accessing weather information (e.g. weather stations, weather forecasts), there is great interest in maintaining traditional knowledge of weather and understanding how modern weather data can be applied to enhance their own knowledge, practice, and skills.

The automated weather station network related to this project continues to provide the community with important information that is used to make decisions about where and when to travel. Discussion with residents shows that this information is particularly important during the open water boating season and also before, during and after periods of storms or bad weather. For people knowledgeable about regional weather patterns, the station information helps them to understand likely weather and ice conditions in other areas they want to travel (i.e. providing additional information to their own knowledge and skills in assessing various environmental conditions).

This project was specifically to extend our previous work on linking Inuit knowledge and weather station data. In addition to continuing to document these sources, we were also able to continue to develop the close relationships we have with individual Elders, hunters, and with the community. These relationships are key to our research that works to bridge different ways of knowing for observing, understanding, and responding to climate and environmental change in this region of the Arctic.
